TitleIssue: Rationalize `IViewEngine` / `ICompositeViewEngine` impedance mismatch <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: ViewResult, ViewViewComponentResult, ... have ViewEngine properties of type IViewEngine. However, the default value is found looking up the ICompositeViewEngine interface in DI. This is both counter-intuitive and overly-restrictive. For example, users can't register the RazorViewEngine itself as the default view engine (disabling MvcViewOptions.ViewEngines because they don't need that indirection). Suggest we instead register the CompositeViewEngine using the IViewEngine interface. Note ICompositeViewEngine is basically a marker interface wrapping IViewEngine; it just adds a property used only in tests. Nothing is currently registered as an IViewEngine in DI.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: Remove `IActionFilter`, `IAsyncActionFilter`, `IDisposable` implementations from `Controller` <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
As I mentioned in #4639,
The MVC filter invocation infrastructure handles both asynchronous and synchronous filters just fine.
So, the virtual methods in Controller for IActionFilter and IAsyncActionFilter don't do enough to be worthwhile. At best they made it clear controllers can be action filters -- a documentation issue. And the IDisposable implementation in Controller is similarly anemic. The DefaultControllerActivator handles the case where a controller is disposable but doesn't require it. If any of these interface implementations are valuable, they should be included in ControllerBase instead. None of these interfaces are linked to view features. Might be good to have a clear non-view / view split between ControllerBase and Controller.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: TryUpdateModelAsync and TryValidateModel have odd overloads <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
When verifying these two methods for sign off I found it confusing that I had flexibility with one (providing a value provider) but not the other. Even odder was that I could provide a custom value provider but not a model binder. I'd expect them to both be flexible and allow for custom validators/binders/value providers OR have neither and rely on a consumer to modify what's on the control prior to calling into them. Oddities:
  • TryUpdateModelAsync gives you the ability to provide an IValueProvider to update with but not an IModelBinder.
  • TryValidateModel doesn't allow you to provide an IModelValidator of any sort.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: FromRoute parameters aren't URL Decoded. <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
[HttpGet][Route("")]public async Task<IActionResult> GetValue([FromQuery(Name = "value")] String value) { ... }[HttpGet][Route("{value}")]public async Task<IActionResult> GetValue([FromRoute(Name = "value")] String value) { ... }
In the first example, a URL encoded string passed as the value query string parameter will be decoded before being passed into the GetValue function. In the second example, a URL encoded string passed as a route segment will NOT be URL decoded before being passed to the GetValue function. This behavior is unexpected, I would expect both Route and Query parameters to be URL decoded before being passed to the function. If this is expected behavior, is there a workaround or a way to tell the route to decode before passing the parameter through? The problem is made more complex in my real world example because the route parameter is a URL and I want the parameter to be a Uri rather than a String. My current solution is to accept a String parameter and then construct a new Uri(value) out of it. However, this means I don't benefit from ModelState validation since the only a string is necessary to have the model state be valid.
Issue closing motivation(s): Not a bug

TitleIssue: File input doesn't get bound on nested models <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Description

When binding nested models, file inputs get ignored if they are the only input on given submodel (works fine on root model). Modified HelloMvc from cli-samples: https://github.com/Kukkimonsuta/nested-file-binding

Setup

public class RootModel{    public ChildModel Child { get; set; }}public class ChildModel{    public string Text { get; set; }    public IFormFile File { get; set; }}
<!-- form1 --><input type='file' name='child.file' />
<!-- form2 --><input type='file' name='child.file' /><input type='text' name='child.text' />

Expected behaviour

  • form1 binds RootModel.Child.File creating instance of both RootModel and ChildModel
  • form2 binds RootModel.Child.File and RootModel.Child.Text creating instance of both RootModel and ChildModel

Actual behaviour

  • form1 will create instance of RootModel and ignore ChildModel leaving it null
  • form2 works as expected
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: Optimize processing of indexer expressions in ExpressionHelper.InsertIndexerInvocationText <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
If a Razor view has several indexer expressions in HtmlHelpers/TagHelpers as shown below 
for (var i = 0; i < Model.Count; i++){            <div class="contact-card">                @Html.LabelFor(m => Model[i].HomePhone)                <b id="@Html.IdFor(m => Model[i].HomePhone)">@Model[i].HomePhone</b>                <br />                @Html.LabelFor(m => Model[i].Mobile)                <b id="@Html.IdFor(m => Model[i].Mobile)">@Model[i].Mobile</b>                <br />                @Html.LabelFor(m => Model[i].MailId)                <b id="@Html.IdFor(m => Model[i].MailId)">@Model[i].MailId</b>                <br />                @Html.LabelFor(m => Model[i].CurrentJob)                <b id="@Html.IdFor(m => Model[i].CurrentJob)">@Model[i].CurrentJob</b>                <br />                @Html.LabelFor(m => Model[i].PastJobs)                @Html.ActionLink("Edit", "Edit", new { id = Model[i].MailId })            </div>}
ExpressionHelper.InsertIndexerInvocationText is invoked to resolve the value of the indexer "i" each time it is used. In the above case, it is invoked 13 times per iteration.
The value of the indexer expression is resolved by using CachedExpressionCompiler.Process.
This is fairly expensive as it goes through the CompileSlow path causing the expression to be compiled each time. When an expression is a member access within a captured local, CachedExpressionCompiler caches the delegate. In our case each of the indexer expression is originally a Member Access Expression over a captured local, but the cache is not used because of the following
var converted = Expression.Convert(indexExpression, typeof(object)); that we do before calling into CachedExpressionCompiler.Process . This conversion is needed because CachedExpressionCompiler is a generic class on the result type of expression. One possible solution is to create a separate non generic version of CachedExpressionCompiler that returns an object specifically to be used by ExpressionHelper.InsertIndexerInvocationText or any other better solutions need to be explored.
Related : #3921
Issue opening motivation(s): Functional Aspects - Reported a bug####Problem - Performance issue
Issue closing motivation(s): Bug - Impossible to fix the issue or too expensive change

TitleIssue: `ViewExecutor.ExecuteAsync()` should `throw` if passed `viewData: null` <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: The part of 0b8fe87 (from PR #3310) which allowed viewData: null to be passed into ViewExecutor.ExecuteAsync() is no longer necessary. Controller.ViewData ensures [Partial]ViewResult.ViewData is non-null when created. So user code would need to manually set [Partial]ViewResult.ViewData to null or instantiate a result directly and never set the property for ViewExecutor.ExecuteAsync() to see viewData: null. Other than two tests specifically for the ExecuteAsync(), nothing uses this "capability". See also #4394.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: `ViewContext.ViewData` should `throw` if set to `null` <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: A ViewContext instance cannot be created with ViewData == null; even the test-only constructor sets the property appropriately. However the ViewData property has no null checks in its setter and downstream code compensates for the odd possibility of context.ViewData = null in user code. We should disallow that possibility i.e. throw an ArgumentNullException and remove ViewExecutorTest.ExecuteAsync_ViewResultAllowNull() -- the only code that uses this "capability".

It should also be no problem if the consumer is using Newtonsoft.Json, where MissingMemberHandling is set to Ignore by default. This would simply set missing properties to default(T).

TitleIssue: Allow link/script tag helpers to generate cache bust for external files. <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Right now, asp-append-version will generate a cache bust based on the file's bits, and cache that version string for future requests. However, if the file is externally sourced, i.e. a CDN, asp-append-version cannot calculate this version string. I see 2 good solutions to this:
  1. Go ahead and download the external file, calculate the version string, and then cache that - sure the initial calculation will take a little longer than if the file existed on local disk, but not too long, right?
  2. Create a new tag helper attribute like asp-prepend-cdn-domain, or whatever, and simply prepend that string value to the original src/href. (I actually implemented this for our needs, very simple but not worthy to go in the core codebase)

TitleIssue: Support flagged enums for various scenarios <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
There are several times I would have like to have this functionality; sometimes when you have a user-facing system that involves lots of 'flag-setting', flagged enums can be much easier to manage than an explosion of boolean fields. I have noticed that GetEnumSelectList throws an exception for flagged enums, and that model binding does not seem to properly account for flagged enums, nor do checkboxes and tag helpers behave as desired (at least as desired by myself...) I would like to propose the following behaviors:
  • During model binding, if there is an array of values for a given key and the binding target is a flagged enum, interpret each value of the array as a member of that enum and 'or' them all together instead of just taking the first value present in the array
  • When determining the 'current values' for a flagged enum in the model, only consider those combined values that are explicitly defined for the enum (i.e. 3, 7, -1, etc.)
  • During generation of checkbox controls and select list options, in order to determine whether they are selected or checked or not, check to see if the model value contains the flags represented by the value specified for the checkbox/option.
  • During generation of select list items for an enum, don't throw an exception if the enum is flagged. Just proceed as normal
Please let me know any thoughts/concerns.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: Strongly-typed view component. <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
I read about View Components and wonder if there are any plans to make them more compile safe. Right now I'm working on providing something similar to View Components in current ASP.NET MVC 5 stack and it doesn't seems that hard to implement it in strongly-typed fashion. The basic idea is that you have "invoke component" helper function where you provide the component type as type parameter (which makes it strongly typed), and a lambda function that get component instance as argument and returns components result. Everything is strongly typed, no magic strings and Invoke methods with params object[] args). Inside our "invoke component" function we create instance of our component class (using IOC container) and invoke our passed delegate with this component instance, and basing on a model and view name returned by this delegate we render the HTMLs. This is simile proof of concept: The invocation of component in view looks like this: 
@(Html.Component<FooBarController>(c => c.Invoke(foo: "foo", bar: true))
And this is the FooBarController (just a normal controller that returns partial view, it can be also used with Html.Action call): 
public class FooBarController : Controller{    public PartialViewResult Invoke(string foo, bool bar)    {        var viewName = ... //get view name        var model = ... //get model        return PartialView(viewName, model);    }}
And this is the code for Html.Component method (alternative to current IViewComponentHelper.Invoke method): 
public static MvcHtmlString Component<TComponent>(   this HtmlHelper htmlHelper,   Func<TComponent, PartialViewResult> invokeComponent) where TComponent : class{    var instance = IocContainer.Get<TComponent>();    var result = invokeComponent(instance);    var viewName = ((PartialViewResult)result).ViewName;    var viewPath = ... // resolve path to view file basing on you View location convention and viewName                            var component = htmlHelper.Partial(viewPath, new ViewDataDictionary(((PartialViewResult)result).Model));                return component;    }
The code is simplified to just show the idea but I tested it and it's working. Can we have something similar in ASP.NET MVC 6? Maybe we could even have razor support like for TagHelpers. For example we could write such directive: 
@addViewCompoenent "*, MyApp.ViewComponents"
and then this code ("Controller" or "Component" suffix could be omitted, like in C# for attributes): 
@Component.FooBar("foo", bar: true)
would be translated under the hood to something like this: 
@(Html.Component<MyApp.ViewComponents.FooBarController>(c => c.Invoke("foo", bar: true))
we would still get IntelliSense when calling @Component.FooBar("foo", bar: true) just like for TagHelpers in asp-for arguments. Notice that I can even use named arguments, it's just normal method call.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: MVC tag helpers are inconsistent about initially `Clear()`ing content <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Moving an issue mentioned in aspnet/Razor#621 over.
There's also a bug in how MVC uses SetContent(): Those tag helpers currently assume Content is empty but should be clearing what other tag helpers have done.
MVC tag helpers that change Content, PostContent or PostElement currently fall into two groups. These groups should be brought together as much as possible, consistently handling tag helpers that run earlier.
  1. Some e.g. FormTagHelper, InputTagHelper, RenderAtEndOfFormTagHelper, and ValidationSummaryTagHelper initially append. A couple (LabelTagHelper and ValidationMessageTagHelper) check output.IsContentModified before calling content.SetContent(), which also takes previous tag helpers into account (here, giving tag helpers that run before them complete control of the content).
  2. Others e.g. LinkTagHelper, ScriptTagHelper and TextAreaTagHelper start with a call to content.SetContent() to implicitly reset that content. A couple (CacheTagHelper and EnvironmentTagHelper) explicitly call output.SuppressOutput() to reset all output content.
Despite my words in aspnet/Razor#621, my suggestion is to remove all use of SetContent() in MVC tag helpers. CacheTagHelper and EnvironmentTagHelper are likely special cases (because they do not target HTML 5 elements) but Group 1 seems like the winner. (Other options include using SetContent() everywhere or consistently using SetContent() for output.Content and Append[Html]() for other TagHelperOutput properties.) /cc @DamianEdwards Side notes:
  1. No MVC tag helpers append to a TagHelperOutput property more than once. But LinkTagHelper and ScrpitTagHelper have a useless DefaultTagHelperContent that both always add to PostElement. Should instead use PostElement throughout.
  2. Can ignore MVC tag helpers e.g. UrlResolutionTagHelper that only change attributes.
  3. No MVC tag helpers change PreContent or PreElement.
  4. No MVC tag helpers directly call content.Clear().
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: Make framework registrations singleton by default <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: Many of the registrations that MVC makes to the new DI abstractions are with the Transient or Scoped lifestyle. If you take a look at the implementations and their dependencies, you'll see that there is often no reason for them to be transient. A transient component forces all depending components to be transient as well. Failing to make a depending component with a registration equal or less than the dependency can cause all sorts of ugly bugs. This problem is commonly referred to as Captive Dependencies. There is obviously no problem when transient framework components (with their dependencies) are stateless, because it doesn't really makes any difference whether those components are made captive by a consuming component. But problems will start to appear if that framework component starts to have (mutable) state in a future release. Since that framework component is registered as transient or scoped, it is -in a strict sense- allowed to get state in a future version of the framework. But if a singleton consumer already depended on that component in v1 (and note that this consumer could both be a 3rd party library component or an end-user component), the application will suddenly break when the user upgrades to the next version. These types of problems are usually pretty hard to track down and are therefore very costly to fix. So although transient components seem to communicate to the world that the component has state, adding state to a framework component in the future can still cause applications to break. So in reality, framework components can never get state if they didn't have that in the initial version. To mitigate this, framework components should always be registered as singleton and force their dependencies to be singleton as well. This results in a much simpler mental model, because this can model can be communicated clearly to everybody; the rules are much simpler. Problems are much easier to spot, because the rule now is that a component itself can't have any (mutable) state. If it needs state, it should either request that from another component, or query some cache. In case users replace components with their own and make those components transient/scoped, their application will break much sooner.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: Support for polymorphic model binding <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Copying from UserVoice site https://aspnet.uservoice.com/forums/41201-asp-net-mvc/suggestions/2215338-support-for-polymorphic-model-binding
Please triage as appropiate MVC currently has a nice story around polymorphic models for display purposes using templates. However, this breaks down when you try to post back to the controller. If your base class is abstract, then you get an error that MVC can't create the abstract type (which you don't want anyways because you want it to instantiate the concrete type). If you try to use multiple action methods that differ only by parameter (to handle each subclass) then you get errors about ambiguity. I'd like to see two things added to MVC. First, support overloaded action methods within the same set of attributes. Second, I'd like to see the default model binder able to figure out the concrete type and instantiate that, passing it to either the action method with the right parameter or to the base class parameter.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: Consider transitioning `TagHelper` property `null` checks into `TagHelper.Init` methods. <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
In today's default TagHelpers there are several instances where we check that we've been provided the correct set of TagHeper properties. We should consider moving all of our if (null) => throw checks into the Init method. What does this buy us?
When multiple TagHelpers are running on a single element if one ends up eventually exploding due to invalid parameters being passed in it ensures that the rest of the TagHelpers in the pipeline have not had their Process/ProcessAsync methods called. You could imagine this being valuable in the case that a user for some reason persists some sort of data in a ProcessAsync method only to have the rest of the pipeline fail.
Issue closing motivation(s): Change - Not relevant change

TitleIssue: Suggestion: TagHelper Expanding Child Objects into their own HTML Elements <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
The ASP.NET 5 TagHelper documentation gives the following example: 
public class WebsiteContext{    public Version Version { get; set; }    public int CopyrightYear { get; set; }    public bool Approved { get; set; }    public int TagsToShow { get; set; }}public class WebsiteInformationTagHelper : TagHelper{    public WebsiteContext Info { get; set; }    public override void Process(TagHelperContext context, TagHelperOutput output)    {        output.TagName = "section";        output.Content.SetContent(            $@"<ul><li><strong>Version:</strong> {Info.Version}</li>            <li><strong>Copyright Year:</strong> {Info.CopyrightYear}</li>            <li><strong>Approved:</strong> {Info.Approved}</li>            <li><strong>Number of tags to show:</strong> {Info.TagsToShow}</li></ul>");        output.TagMode = TagMode.StartTagAndEndTag;    }}
This can then be used in your Razor .cshtml as follows: 
<website-information info="new WebsiteContext {    Version = new Version(1, 3),    CopyrightYear = 1790,    Approved = true,    TagsToShow = 131 }"/>
This will generate the following HTML: 
<section>    <ul>        <li><strong>Version:</strong> 1.3</li>        <li><strong>Copyright Year:</strong> 1790</li>        <li><strong>Approved:</strong> true</li>        <li><strong>Number of tags to show:</strong> 131 </li>    </ul></section>
This is pretty ugly tag helper syntax. Is there some way to nest the website-context inside the website-information and get full intelli-sense so that the only allowed child of website-information can be context? See example below: 
<website-information>    <website-context version="1.3" copyright="1790" approved tags-to-show="131"/></website-information>
There are several reasons to do this:
  1. You already had lots of attributes on website-information.
  2. website-context makes more logical sense being a child element.
  3. The website-context properties are logically grouped together and would get lost among other properties on website-information.
  4. You could have multiple website-context elements in a collection.
My own real world application is that I have written a TagHelper to generate Twitter Card and Facebook Open Graph meta tags. I currently have to write this: 
<twitter-card-gallery     username="RehanSaeedUK"     creator-username="RehanSaeedUK"     title="My Title"     image0="new TwitterImage("http://example.com/image0.png", 100, 100)"    image1="new TwitterImage("http://example.com/image1.png", 100, 100)"    image2="new TwitterImage("http://example.com/image2.png", 100, 100)"    image3="new TwitterImage("http://example.com/image3.png", 100, 100)"/>
But I would really like to write this:

TitleIssue: Refactor IRazorPage to write output to a IHtmlContent instead of TextWriter <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: The interface contract for a IRazorPage \ RazorPage is to write to the TextWriter instance exposed via ViewContext.Writer. In the default case (i.e. the user isn't using a custom IRazorView), ViewContext.Writer is an instance of RazorTextWriter which essentially has the same sort of contract \ behavior as IHtmlContent. We could instead change IRazorPage to expose its results as an IHtmlContent instead. This change would allow us a) We can follow the same append pattern we get with appending one IHtmlContent to another used through the remainder of the application. b) Remove the contract that we give special treatment to TextWriter instances that implement IBufferedTextWriter. Also remove IBufferedTextWriter. Related discussion: Since page instrumentation \ BrowserLink will be affected by this interface change, we can follow up with @jodavis to figure out if they can rely on EventNotification instead our current interface based contract.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: `asp-append-version` ignored when running on Mono 4.2 or 4.3 <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: The <img>, <link> and <script> tag helpers mostly work on all platforms. However asp-append-version does nothing when running on Mono 4.2 or 4.3. Since FileVersionProvider contains the only Uri.TryCreate() call in the MVC product code, the root cause is likely aspnet/External#21. Rather than waiting for a Mono fix, should work around the issue e.g. by confirming the new Uri has an "http" or "https" scheme. Note it's been almost two months since @sornaks filed the Xamarin bug for aspnet/External#21. And we don't know when this bug will reach the Mono alpha channel. Further the FileVersionProvider class looks fragile compared with FilePathResult. Though the notion of "absolute" is different for the two classes, they should probably share some of the same smarts.

TitleIssue: Add HtmlHelper which will return the files modification timestamp by glob mask. <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
I want to propose to add HtmlHelper which will return the files modification timestamp by glob mask. This will help in scenarios such as RequireJS module configuration to clear the client scripts cache. I want to present my realisation of this module. 
using Microsoft.AspNet.FileProviders;using Microsoft.AspNet.Hosting;using Microsoft.AspNet.Mvc.Rendering;using Microsoft.Framework.Caching.Memory;using Microsoft.Framework.DependencyInjection;using System;using System.Linq;public static class FilesVersionExtensions{    public static string FilesVersion(this IHtmlHelper helper, string glob)    {        while (new[] { "~", ".", "/", "\\" }.Any(i => glob.StartsWith(i, StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase)))        {            glob = glob.Substring(1);        }        string Result;        if (Cache.TryGetValue(glob, out Result)) return Result;        Result = DateTime.Now.Ticks.ToString();        var env = helper.ViewContext.HttpContext.RequestServices.GetService<IHostingEnvironment>();        if (env != null)        {            Cache.Set(glob, Result, new MemoryCacheEntryOptions().AddExpirationTrigger(new PhysicalFileProvider(env.WebRootPath).Watch(glob)));        }        return Result;    }    private static readonly MemoryCache Cache = new MemoryCache(new MemoryCacheOptions());}
Example of use for the monitoring of all the scripts in a folder and subfolders: 
<script type="text/javascript">        var require = { urlArgs: "v=@Html.FilesVersion("js/**/*.js")" };</script><script data-main="js/test" src="~/js/require.js" asp-file-version="true"></script>
Maybe I did not notice and there is a ready solution? Thank You.

TitleIssue: DisplayNameFor / tag helpers should correctly translate Camel Case <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Currently, when using @Html.DisplayNameFor() or the corresponding tag helpers on properties with Camel Case, it is always required to add a DisplayAttribute to the corresponding model property to resolve the Camel Case property name to a user friendly, space separated name. If no localization takes place, the above is true for about 100 % of all applications. Thus, I suggest to add logic to @Html.DisplayNameFor() to recognize Camel Case or underscore separated property names and to automatically apply a text transformation. By default, property names should be output upper case for the first letter of each fragment:
firstName => "First Name"
first_name => "First Name" There should be an enumeration introduced to have the text transformation been done in a different way:
public enum TextTransform
{
NoTransformation
, FirstFragmentFirstLetterUpperCase
, AllFragmentsFirstLetterLowerCase
, AllFragmentsFirstLetterUpperCase // default value
, AllFragmentsLowerCase
, AllFragmentsUpperCase
} Hence, TextTransform t = TextTransform.{...}; @Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.firstMidName, t) shall result in: @Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.firstMidName, TextTransform.NoTransformation) => "firstMidName"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.firstMidName, TextTransform.FirstFragmentFirstLetterUpperCase) => "First mid name"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.firstMidName, TextTransform.AllFragmentsFirstLetterLowerCase) => "first mid name"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.firstMidName, TextTransform.AllFragmentsFirstLetterUpperCase) => "First Mid Name"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.firstMidName, TextTransform.AllFragmentsLowerCase) => "first mid name"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.firstMidName, TextTransform.AllFragmentsUpperCase) => "FIRST MID NAME" and @Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.first_Mid_nAMe, TextTransform.NoTransformation) => "first_Mid_nAMe"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.first_Mid_nAMe, TextTransform.FirstFragmentFirstLetterUpperCase) => "First mid nAMe"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.first_Mid_nAMe, TextTransform.AllFragmentsFirstLetterLowerCase) => "first mid nAMe"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.first_Mid_nAMe, TextTransform.AllFragmentsFirstLetterUpperCase) => "First Mid NAMe"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.first_Mid_nAMe, TextTransform.AllFragmentsLowerCase) => "first mid name"
@Html.DisplayNameFor(m => m.first_Mid_nAMe, TextTransform.AllFragmentsUpperCase) => "FIRST MID NAME" (OK, the enumeration version is quite verbose. There should be some general method/property to switch text transformation for the whole view, e.g. @Html.DisplayNameTransformation = TextTransform.FirstFragmentFirstLetterUpperCase)
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: What-if-mode for Routes, Binding and Views <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
As a tools author, I would like to be able to create a UI which lets me allow users to do the following for each case:
  • Routes: provide a URI and see how the route is resolved
  • Binding: provide binding data to see what the resulting binding is
  • Views: provide view data to see what view is targeted
This would be used predominately during development to allow various experiments to take place. It wouldn't replace unit testing, etc, but would serve as a what-if-mode for developers who are learning or trying out various options. After talking with @rynowak it looks like there really isn't a happy path for this at the moment, but with a combination of some basic instrumentation and diagnostics APIs (which are under development for other purposes anyway) this could be made possible.

TitleIssue: Escaped characters in url parameters in beta4 <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
We use webapi for an internal api, but some of the resource identifiers have a \ in their name. I tried escaping those characters in the url, but it looks like that MVC unescapes urls before parsing them for routing causing it to either not find the route, or give the wrong value as a parameter. Added to that, it seems that a \ will be converted to a / so even if I use a greedy parameter it still results in the wrong value. Examples:
route: "list/{id}"
url "list/test"
Matches route but gives "test" as a value for id route: "list/{id}"
url "list/test%5C"
Matches route but gives "test" as a value for id route: "list/{*id}"
url "list/test%5C"
Matches route but gives "test/" as a value for id
Issue closing motivation(s): Bug - Impossible to fix the issue or too expensive change

TitleIssue: [Suggestion] A New Attribute Needed For a simple parameter when doing "Post" by jQuery in Web Api <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Hello:
You see that if I let my jQuery call something like this: 
   $.post("http://localhost:8080/",dataType:"json",data:{"id":"1"},);
And my actual Web Api defines: 
   public int Post([FromBody] string id) {}
This is wrong. And I have to write something like this: 
  $.post("http://localhost:8080/",dataType:"json",data:{"":"1"},);
For a single parameter posted, I must leave the "key" empty. However for a complicated type defined in the server, I can combine a json object (something like {"id":"1","name":"Bill Gates"}). And this will be reflected into the object at the server side. In fact, what we want is if I can write something like this below when passing a single value by Post at the server side: 
   public int Post([FromBodyForSingle] string id)   //If I use something like this attribute, "id" will be readout directly through the "Post" method.
And at the client side, I can write: 
   $.post("http://localhost:8080/",dataType:"json",data:{"id":"1"},);   //what if we can keep the "id" here to map the parameter name defined in my method, to make it empty is really an ugly thing....
In my mind, the design would be better if:
  1. "FromBodyForSingleAttribute" is a new attribute ONLY FOR a single variable passed by "Post" to a Web Api's method.
  2. "FromBodyAttribute" will actually pass a json object by "Post" to a Web Api's method.
  3. "FromBodyAttribute" can only be used once in a method parameters, "FromBodyForSingleAttribute" can be used many times.
I'm not sure whether this situation also happens in FromUriAttribute?
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Consistent authorization inheritance <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Now, you can use AuthorizeAttribute to specify that controller or action needs authorization. If action can be accessed anonymously, AllowAnonymousAttribute can be used to override AuthorizeAttribute. But once you add AllowAnonymousAttribute on your controller you can't override it, which is kind of confusing, especially in situations then controllers inherit from custom base controllers. Here are some example, demonstrating the confusion: 
[Authorize]public class HomeController : Controller{    [AllowAnonymous]    public IActionResult Index()    {        // Action can be accessed anonymously as expected        return View();    }}[AllowAnonymous]public class HomeController : Controller{    [Authorize]    public IActionResult Index()    {        // Action can be accessed anonymously, even though authorize attribute is most specific one        return View();    }}[Authorize]public class HomeController : BaseController{    [Authorize]    public IActionResult Index()    {        // Action can be accessed anonymously, even though authorize attribute is all over the place,        // but you can't see that AllowAnonymousAttribute is being used on base controller.        return View();    }}
Wouldn't it be better to have authorization based on most specific first, similar to RouteConstraintAttribute?
I believe this would bring some consistency within authorization attribute usage.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Some model binders ignore `[FromQuery]` and similar value source filters <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
The model binders with their own sources ignore filtering a parent model binder imposes on the value providers. For example an action parameter such as [FromQuery] FormCollection collection or [FromQuery] IFormFile file does not bind to null as expected (when there's a file in the request in the second case). This doesn't make conceptual sense and the result may be user confusion. Suggest two things:
  • confirm the logically-associated value provider is currently enabled in model binders with their own sources.
    • for the two examples above, this means FormCollectionModelBinder and FormFileModelBinder should confirm ModelBindingContext.ValueProvider includes a value provider for BindingSource.Form. (IBindingSourceValueProvider.Filter(BindingSource.Form) might be of use.)
  • add an explicit BindingSource.Request and / or a RequestValueProvider that is enabled by default. this would give CancellationTokenModelBinder something to check.
(Greedy model binders also have their own sources but the override of a parent's filtering is explicit when they are used.)
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: `[FromServices]` properties in base `Controller` should not be present in `ModelState` <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Unless you have a POCO controller, the following entries will be present in ModelState: 
{    "ModelState": {        "MetadataProvider": { "Value": null, "Errors": [ ], "ValidationState": 3 },        "Url": { "Value": null, "Errors": [ ], "ValidationState": 3 },        "ObjectValidator": { "Value": null, "Errors": [ ], "ValidationState": 3 },        "TempData": { "Value": null, "Errors": [ ], "ValidationState": 3 }    }}
All of the above are properties on the base Controller class and all have associated [FromServices] attributes. Basically what we model bind is unfortunately treated identically to what the user requested. Users are likely to ask two questions when they see these entries e.g. when debugging invalid models:
  1. What are those properties doing in the (perhaps "my") ModelState?
  2. Is it important that those entries are in ModelValidationState.Skipped state?
Suggest we avoid both questions. That is special-case properties of the base Controller, either eliminating them from ModelState or never validating them (so they aren't added in the first place).
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Provide alternate ways to add version to a file path for cache busting. <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: Currently the only way to add version to a file path is query string. That is, http://someurl.com/hello becomes http://someurl.com/hello?v=hashed_string. But some popular proxies do not cache the query string at all. As a result, it is not cache busted : http://www.stevesouders.com/blog/2008/08/23/revving-filenames-dont-use-querystring/ An alternate is to provide an option to modify the file name itself. I suggest it look something like: <script src="js/something.js" asp-file-version="true" asp-file-version-method="filename" />. Depending on asp-file-version-method we could modify the method appropriately.

TitleIssue: Input formatters should also check for supported encodings when selecting a formatter to read the stream <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: When trying to find a formatter which can deserialize a request, we currently only look at the the supported media types to check if the request media type matches it, but we should also consider matching the request content's charset value to the supported content encodings of a formatter. TitleIssue: Anti-forgery token infrastructure not extensible <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: As it currently stands the anti-forgery token infrastructure is perfect for dealing with pages that submit form data. The token is placed in a hidden field and this is submitted along with the rest of the form data. On the server AntiForgeryTokenStore extracts the token from both the form and from the cookie to allow for comparison.  It is becoming common practice that data is submitted in JSON format over a POST request. This behaviour is supported by MVC currently using the [FromBody] attribute for model binding. The token can easily be extracted client side by taking the value from the form field and including it in the post. However there is no way to instruct the AntiForgeryTokenStore to take its value from the body of the post and not from the form collection.  My approach would be to create a new implementation of ITokenStore which could take its value from a JSON payload in the body. However ITokenStore is marked internal. It would be nice if this interface could be exposed as an extension point. It seems odd that FromBody is supported but in doing so there is no way to use anti-forgery tokens.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Consider using IMemoryCache with sliding expiration for ViewLocationExpanderCache <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
• We could consider switching the DefaultViewLocationExpanderCache to use an IMemoryCache instance. This way we could apply sliding expiration policies to evict cached view locations after some time (~5mins?).
  • We build keys in DefaultViewLocationExpanderCache but don't hash them (https://github.com/aspnet/Mvc/blob/dev/src/Microsoft.AspNet.Mvc.TagHelpers/CacheTagHelper.cs#L172-L177). Since an arbitrary number of expanders can be added, we should consider hashing to avoid giant dictionary keys.

TitleIssue: Add support for camel casing in the default json contract resolver  <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
If a custom contract resolver is shipped out of the box to support #468, then it would be difficult for end users to support what CamelCasePropertyNamesContractResolver does.
Example:
If we ship with out of box a custom contract resolver called JsonContractResolver, a user ideally should derive from this resolver and then configure for camel casing. But Json.net currently doesn't have an easy way to do this and only has the big hammer of using CamelCasePropertyNamesContractResolver. But using this resolver will remove all the important settings that we have in custom contract resolver. So as part of this bug we should have out of box support for camel case and provide an easy way to configure this (probably at our formatter level?...like example: jsonformatter.CamelCasePropertyNames = true)
Code which is usable in this case: https://github.com/OData/WebApi/blob/master/OData/src/System.Web.OData/OData/Builder/LowerCamelCaser.cs#L64
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Not relevant request

TitleIssue: Provide option to extend select list to contain current value <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: Today, if a user passes a select list containing { 1, 2, 3, } to @Html.DropDownList(), related methods, or the <select> tag helper when the expression value is 4, the generated <select/> will look like nothing is selected. This is true whether or not 4 would cause a validation error on submission. Suggest automatically extending the select list to { 1, 2, 3, 4, }, then select and disable the corresponding <option/> element. For back-compatibility and to cover the tag helper case where the Razor source already contains an explicit <option/> for 4, this should be opt-in. That is, add bool appendCurrentValue parameters and asp-append-current-value attributes to the relevant HTML and tag helpers. FYI the MVC 5 enum helpers (@Html.EnumDropDownListFor()) unconditionally ensured the current enum value was included in the generated <option/> elements and selected. Could reuse some of that code (though not all of the semantics -- bit quirky and enum-specific in retrospect).

TitleIssue: Add `ModelStateDictionary` methods to clear or set contained values <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
• related to scenarios described in #1231 and #1517
  • provide new ModelStateDictionary.ClearValues() method which removes all values but leaves all errors (and exceptions) alone
    • might require a new ModelState property indicating it has no real value or a small change where we read from the dictionary
  • provide new ModelStateDictionary.SetValue<TModel, TValue>([NotNull] Expression<Func<TModel, TValue>> expression, TValue value) and ModelStateDictionary.SetValue([NotNull] string expression, object value) methods
    • methods should create a ModelState entry if none exists and overwrite existing entry (leaving any errors or exceptions alone) if any
    • note action author must provide TModel explicitly when using first overload e.g. ModelState.SetValue<Customer>(m => m.Name, "banana") or ModelState.SetValue((Customer m) => m.Name, "banana")
    • in addition action author should update the model passed to the view. otherwise display helpers or direct use of @Model.Property could show something different than value passed to these new methods. (if this turns out to be too confusing, could instead let authors write e.g. ModelState.ClearValue<Customer>(m => m.Name) or recommend ModelState.SetValue<Customer>(m => m.Name, customer.Name).)

TitleIssue: Support Func<Stream> for both StreamOutputFormatter and FileStreamResult <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
The purpose of this is to delay the stream creation to the action result execution time. This allows
  1. Doing the work only when we know we absolutely have to do it. e.g. the result can be replaced by a filter.
  2. Easier dealing with disposal, without this the user is ultimately responsible to dispose the stream if something failed along the way before the action result was executed (and if we don't make setting the stream a registration step for disposal).
[MyFilter]public Stream GetStream(){   var stream = new MemoryStream();   // do more   return stream;}
Today the user has to write something explicit to be sure disposal happens, perhaps this: 
// alt1[MyFilter]public Stream GetStream(){   var stream = new MemoryStream();   try   {      // do more   }   catch   {      stream.Dispose();      throw;   }   return stream;}// alt2[MyFilter]public Stream GetStream2(){   var stream = new MemoryStream();      RegisterForDisposal(stream); // this doesn't exist yet in the framework.   // do more   return stream;}
With this suggestion the formatter will just look like: 
WriteAsync(Func<Stream> func){   using(var stream = func())   {             // validity check      await stream.CopyToAsync(Response.Body);   }}
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Not relevant request

TitleIssue: Provide predictable ordering of validation summary messages and `@Html.Display()` / `@Html.Editor()` properties <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
to ensure a predictable order using MVC once #964 is fixed, users must annotate all model properties with [Display(Order=x)]. this may be too high a bar but unfortunately type.GetRuntimeProperties() and related Reflection methods do not guarantee a predictable or even a stable ordering. recent decision was to split this issue from #964 and to determine what guarantees exist for the type.GetRuntimeProperties() return value. then, if no guarantees exist (as MSDN implies), ask for one or add something (perhaps not based on PropertyName) to MVC. details and history
see also the StackOverflow discussion of Reflection ordering as well as the linked MSDN documentation. in #964:
MVC 5.2 does not provide a predictable property order when displaying / editing a complex object or filling in the @Html.ValidationSummary(). We could do a bit better here and sort by Order then by PropertyName.
in PR #1866:
I'm not sure I quite follow the reasoning for adding ordering by Name, is it the same behavior as MVC5? Can you illustrate the benefit?

we had an offline discussion (sorry, not sure who all was there) where we agreed to make the property order predictable. today, it's possible for the HTML Html.DisplayFor(...) (for example) generates to change between CLR or Roslyn builds. with this fix in place, the UI will remain consistent no matter how the runtime and compiler choose to order properties.
MVC 5 does not provide such a predictable property order. the offline discussion basically supported my comment in #964:
We could do a bit better here and sort by Order then by PropertyName.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Async IModelValidator <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: The Validate method on Microsoft.AspNet.Mvc.ModelBinding.IModelValidator should be ValidateAsync. Sure, validating DataAnnotations, etc. are sync. However, some validation is not.  One simple example is checking the availability of a UserName during user registration. This usually involves some query of a data store, which is clearly async work. But since the interface does not allow for this, this validation will have to be done at some different time in the pipeline. The framework comes up short in this case. Not ideal.  To validate synchronously with ValidateAsync, return Task.FromResult(errors). No problem. And if you do need to query a data store, async work is enabled.

TitleIssue: Centralized attribute routes <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Some users have asked about still maintaining all the routes in a centralized location for a webapi style project. We explicitly decided not to support conventional routing in this scenario, but with the ApplicationModel its relatively straightforward to write some extension method on top of routes that will allow making an attribute route apply to a controller or an action. This is just a strawman suggestion, it needs to be cleaned up For the simple case 
    routes.AddGet("Receipts/{id}", => ReceiptsController.GetReceipt);
Or for the fancier user 
    routes.AddRoute("Receipts/{Id}", => ReceiptsController);    routes.AddGet("", => ReceiptsController.GetReceipt);    routes.AddDelete("", => ReceiptsController.DeleteReceipt);    routes.Add("Patch", "", => ReceiptsController.FixReceipt); // custom Http constraint
These will in turn create application models. Since the application models live off the MvcOptions we can change the signature of UseMvc to expose an IMvcRouteBuilder instead of IRouteBuilder that will provide the access to options. This will not be a breaking change if IMvcRouteBuilder implements IRouteBuilder. Alternatively we can make this API live off the MvcOptions 
    services.ConfigureOptions<MvcOptions>( options =>    {        options.AddRoute ...    }
The downside is that it is not as intuitive. CC / @rynowak @loudej @davidfowl
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Not relevant request

TitleIssue: Mixing of MVC and API style <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
I'm not sure yet if the new style of using an mvc controller for api functionality is the best idea.
MVC Controllers do totally different things from an api controller. Sure, the old way (seprate filter attributes and so on) was censored. But what about things like discovering all api controllers? This was used for the help page, right?
Also a mvc controller does not have a need for returning only status codes. An api controller has.
In some cases I want different authentication options for mvc and api.
For example:
What if i want my api to use only tokens and my mvc controllers to use a cookie based authentication. In the vNext world everything is a nuget package. Perfect.
But: Do I need content negotiation, json formaters and all those api features in a pure mvc project? No. The same is for a pure api project. Do I need razor in a pure API project? No. Maybe you should consider to re-split those two worlds while sharing as much code as you can?

TitleIssue: Views should be able to trigger a background flush while they continue processing aka Make Razor flush awesome <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
This is a proposed enhancement to the flush point support in Razor views. Currently, views can force a flush to the client by calling FlushAsync, e.g. 
<!doctype html><head>    <title>Flushy</title>    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" /></head>@{await FlushAsync();}<body>...
This is awesome, but there are two problems:
  1. Calling the method is ugly. Because it's void returning, it has to be invoked inside a code block (@{ }) which isn't particularly discoverable.
  2. Awaiting the flush (which is definitely the right thing to do given it's current implementation) causes the view rendering to pause until the flush completes. Typically, the flush will actually be synchronous and the method will return immediately, as it's simply copying the bytes down to the next buffer in the stack (e.g. the TCP/IP outgoing buffer), and in those cases, this is fine. However, sometimes, it will be async, and when that happens, the view effectively stops processing until the flush has completed.
The proposal is to add a new, string returning Flush method to the view (the returned string would be null/empty and is only to allow the simplified call site). This method would attempt a FlushAsync call inline and if it returned synchronously would do nothing more. If it returned async however, it would return back to the view immediately, while managing the completion of the flush along with coordination with any subsequent calls to Flush by the view. This way, the view continues to process even though an async flush may currently be in progress. The number/size of outstanding flush operations should be limited so that back-pressure can still be honored, in which case the call to Flush would block. At the end of the view processing, it would async wait for all outstanding async flush operations until continuing on with response processing. As an example, the view might now look like this: 
<!doctype html><head>    <title>Flushy</title>    <link rel="stylesheet" href="styles.css" /></head>@Flush()<body>    <h1>My Flushy Page</h1>    <h2>First Set of Items</h2>    <ul>        @foreach (var item in await Model.Items1.ToListAsync()) {            <li>@item</li>        }    </ul>    @Flush()    @* This second Flush() will get queued behind the first Flush() if the first was async and is still in progress *@    <h2>Second Set of Items</h2>    <ul>        @foreach (var item in await Model.Items2.ToListAsync()) {            <li>@item</li>        }    </ul></body>
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Unable to set `ViewBag` or `ViewData` entries from `Controller` constructors <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
The following works in MVC 5.2 but throws an InvalidOperationException in vNext. This prevents common initialization scenarios unless the user is aware of OnActionExecuting() or OnActionExecutionAsync() (which are less discoverable than MVC 5.2's Initialize() method). ViewData["Items"] doesn't help because ViewData is null. 
public class HomeController : Controller{  private static readonly IEnumerable<SelectListItem> _items =    new SelectList(Enumerable.Range(7, 13));  public HomeController()  {    ViewBag.Items = _items;  }  ...}
Details:
The root cause is DefaultControllerActivator creates the controller's ViewDataDictionary instance. So ViewData is null until Controller instances are activated. Worse if ViewBag is used while ViewData is still null, the result is an InvalidOperationException thrown from the DynamicViewData.ViewData getter. By contrast, few properties in the MVC 5.2 Controller class even return null (let alone throw) if invoked from the constructor. (Exceptions include ControllerContext, Url, and anything ControllerContext-derived e.g. HttpContext and User. All of those simply return null prior to the Initialize() call.) Probably need to revisit the Controller activation model. At least should look at the properties lazy-initialized in MVC 5.2 and decide if they should be handled similarly in vNext.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Unable to use tag helpers for the entire `Model` <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Put another way: Unable to use tag helpers for model => model expressions. E.g. simple views like

__Microsoft_AspNet_Mvc_TagHelpers_InputTagHelper.For =  CreateModelExpression(__model => __model.);
Note the invalid period before the close parenthesis. There's nothing I can put in a for or validation-for attribute that leads to generation of: 
  CreateModelExpression(__model => __model);
In addition the ModelExpression constructor throws an ArgumentException if the passed name is string.Empty -- the expected value in this case.
The generation part of this bug shares a root cause with #1345 and should probably be fixed at the same time. Unfortunately it'll likely require a change in Razor.
Could for example pass the user's text (as well as the renderAttributeValue rendering Action) to MvcTagHelperAttributeValueCodeRenderer.RenderAttributeValue(). Then RenderAttributeValue() would special-case the lambda's RHS -- __model then call renderAttributeValue (empty and indexer cases) versus __model. the the same call (otherwise).

TitleIssue: Allow replacement of `Id` sanitization <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: HTML continues to evolve and users may have many different Id uniqueness or sanitization requirements. For example a user who values uniqueness more than Unobtrusive validation or other CSS selectors, might want no sanitization at all. Others may want to sanitize only characters that are known to cause issues in CSS selectors. @DamianEdwards and I talked about one way to address these various requirements. We could make Id sanitization a service MVC grabs from DI to meet the above requirement. Current MVC 6.0 code uses a static method in TagBuilder pretty much the opposite of an extensibility point. FYI default sanitization will match MVC 5.2. That provides Id values which match HTML 4 requirements. So by default we could be sacrificing some uniqueness when names contain "invalid" characters. Including Needs Design label per an offline comment from @yishaigalatzer

            // We should have a robust and centrallized version of this code. See HttpAbstractions#28            Contract.Assert(path != null);            var url = path;            if (!string.IsNullOrEmpty(fragment))            {                url += "#" + fragment;            }            if (string.IsNullOrEmpty(protocol) && string.IsNullOrEmpty(host))            {                // We're returning a partial url (just path + query + fragment), but we still want it                // to be rooted.                if (!url.StartsWith("/", StringComparison.Ordinal))                {                    url = "/" + url;                }                return url;            }            else            {                protocol = string.IsNullOrEmpty(protocol) ? "http" : protocol;                host = string.IsNullOrEmpty(host) ? _httpContext.Request.Host.Value : host;                url = protocol + "://" + host + url;                return url;            }

public class MediaTypeHeaderValue    {        public MediaTypeHeaderValue();        public string Charset { get; set; }        public string MediaSubType { get; set; }        public string MediaType { get; set; }        public MediaTypeHeaderValueRange MediaTypeRange { get; set; }        public IDictionary<string, string> Parameters { get; set; }        public string RawValue { get; }        public static MediaTypeHeaderValue Parse(string input);        public static bool TryParse(string input, out MediaTypeHeaderValue headerValue);        protected static Dictionary<string, string> ParseParameters(string inputString);        //        // Summary:        //     Determines whether this instance is a subset of passed Microsoft.AspNet.Mvc.HeaderValueAbstractions.MediaTypeHeaderValue.        //     If the media type and media type parameters of this media type are all present        //     and match those of otherMediaType then it is a match even though otherMediaType        //     may have additional parameters.        //        // Parameters:        //   mediaType:        //     The first media type.        //        //   otherMediaType:        //     The second media type.        //        // Returns:        //     true if this is a subset of otherMediaType; false otherwise.        public bool IsSubsetOf(MediaTypeHeaderValue otherMediaType);    }

TitleIssue: Input Formatters : Request ContentType missing for post requests  <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
the http spec says
"Any HTTP/1.1 message containing an entity-body SHOULD include a Content-Type header field defining the media type of that body. If and only if the media type is not given by a Content-Type field, the recipient MAY attempt to guess the media type via inspection of its content and/or the name extension(s) of the URI used to identify the resource. If the media type remains unknown, the recipient SHOULD treat it as type "application/octet-stream". " Right now input formatters are not selected. and the response is 415. We should try setting with application/octetStream.

TitleIssue: Make `@Html.Display()` and `@Html.Editor()` order properties by name <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
MVC 5.2 and (soon, see issue #964 and PR #1010) 6.0 order properties in the @Html.Display() and @Html.Editor() return values using the ModelMetadata.Order property. This produces as stable an order as Linq's OrderBy() -- leaves the properties in their original order. But the order isn't predictable because the CLR doesn't guarantee an order the Type.GetRuntimeProperties() extension method returns properties. The point may be moot if Type.GetRuntimeProperties() happens to order properties consistently and not by (say) the order they appear in the IL. But we could ensure a predictable order by adding ThenBy(m => m.Name) to our current sort (in the ModelMetadata.Properties lazy-init getter) Some questions:
  • Is this necessary? That is are properties ordered by name or something equally obvious already?
  • Would the additional sorting have any downsides? For example performance could be an issue because the Properties enumeration isn't initialized in our ModelMetadata prototype cache.

My request url is /products/search?searchterm=adidas, which indicates that the user doesn't care about a particular categorie and is searching for the term in all categories... Workaround
The user can instantiate the collection himself in the constructor 
    public class Product    {        public int Id { get; set; }        public string Name { get; set; }        public string Manufacturer { get; set; }        public ProductCategoryType Category { get; set; }    }    public enum ProductCategoryType    {        Books,        Movies,        Sports,        Clothing    }    public class SearchCriteria    {        public SearchCriteria()        {            // Workaround            //this.Categories = new List<ProductCategoryType>();        }        public List<ProductCategoryType> Categories { get; set; }        [Required]        public string SearchTerm { get; set; }    }    public class ProductsController :Controller    {        private static List<Product> allProducts = null;        static ProductsController()        {            // products            allProducts = new List<Product>();            allProducts.Add(new Product()            {                Id = 1,                Name = "Adidas Brazuca 2014 Top Glider",                Manufacturer = "Adidas",                Category = ProductCategoryType.Sports            });            allProducts.Add(new Product()            {                Id = 2,                Name = "CLR via C#",                Manufacturer = "Microsoft Press",                Category = ProductCategoryType.Books            });            allProducts.Add(new Product()            {                Id = 3,                Name = "Adidas Mens Mirror Trefoil Logo Tee Shirt",                Manufacturer = "Adidas",                Category = ProductCategoryType.Clothing            });        }        [HttpGet]        public ActionResult Search(SearchCriteria criteria)        {            if (!ModelState.IsValid)            {                return new HttpStatusCodeResult(400);            }            var filteredProdcuts = from category in criteria.Categories                                   join product in allProducts                                   on category equals product.Category                                   where product.Name.IndexOf(criteria.SearchTerm, StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase) >= 0                                   select product;            return new ObjectResult(filteredProdcuts);        }    }

TitleIssue: Add antiforgery overload that will implicitly process existing cookie token <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
There is a decent amount of complexity in AntiForgery.GetHtml(context) which internally handles the existing cookie token (if it exists) and generates new tokens appropriately. We are using AntiForgery to generate tokens for Web API calls. There is no HTML input involved and we don't want to reproduce the internal complexities of obtaining and validating existing cookie tokens. Our code also shouldn't care about cookie tokens (old or new) because AntiForgery already contains this logic should abstract this away for us. It would be good if there was an overload like the following which would obtain and process any old cookie just like GetHtml does. 
public AntiForgeryTokenSet GetTokens([NotNull] HttpContext context)
In the same way, validation could also implicitly obtain the current cookie token rather than having the caller provide this value. From our perspective, we have a token (conceptually the form token but passed in either the header or querystring) which we want to obtain and then later validate. A good set of signatures to support this could be 
public AntiForgeryTokenSet GetTokens([NotNull] HttpContext context)public void Validate([NotNull] HttpContext context, string formToken)
To avoid this complexity, our current hack/workaround is to call GetHtml and parse out the value using a regular expression.

TitleIssue: Correlation functionality within Web API <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: WCF for years has had built-in correlation functionality allowing to correlate distributed parts of application. Unfortunately Web API correlation is limited to a single service boundary. We lack ability to correlate processes between client and server, as well as interconnected services that is widely used by many distributed SOA applications. It would be highly beneficial to have this functionality as part of framework. As a solution, I can offer/contribute this project https://webapicorrelator.codeplex.com/ that surely can be improved and extended as necessary.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Already Implemented feature request by an external contributor of the project

TitleIssue: Modelbinding provides null value when none of the sub-model properties are available <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Please note that this is a change from MVC 5. Run this sample code in both MVC 5 and MVC 6. 
public class MyModel{    public string Prop1 { get; set; }    public string Prop2 { get; set; }    public string Prop3 { get; set; }    public string Prop4 { get; set; }}public class HomeController : Controller{    public IActionResult About(MyModel model)    {        return Content((model == null).ToString());    }}
Then request these URLs:
  • http://localhost:57097/Home/About
  • http://localhost:57097/Home/About?model.Prop1=hello
On MVC 5 you get False, False.
On MVC 6 you get True, False. That is, in MVC 6 model binding instantiates the model object only if at least one of the sub-properties is present (the model is created on demand, instead of eagerly).
Issue closing motivation(s): Not a bug -  Unclear/wrong usage of a functionality

TitleIssue: Support IServiceProvider Injection for DataAnnotations validations through DependencyResolver <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Porting this from https://aspnetwebstack.codeplex.com/workitem/463. With the new dependency injection system, I'm guessing that this will be more meaningful. I wonder what you guys think.

Original Issue

I am not completely sure but at first glance, it seems to me that IServiceProvider for DataAnnotations validations is completely ignored in ASP.NET Web API. Here is a quote from
Jeff Handley's blog post (http://jeffhandley.com/archive/2010/10/25/RiaServicesValidationContext.aspx): "Consider the scenario where a validator needs to access the database; you certainly wouldnt couple a validation method to your data access layer, would you? Instead, you would make your repository available as a service that your validation method can consume in a loosely-coupled manner. In order to easily support these scenarios, ValidationContext implements IServiceProvider. This interface requires a single method, GetService(Type). Using GetService, a validation method can access your repository without knowing how to instantiate or initialize it." Here is the Validate method of the DataAnnotationsModelValidator class: 
  public override IEnumerable<ModelValidationResult> Validate(ModelMetadata metadata, object container)  {      // Per the WCF RIA Services team, instance can never be null (if you have      // no parent, you pass yourself for the "instance" parameter).      ValidationContext context = new ValidationContext(container ?? metadata.Model, null, null);      context.DisplayName = metadata.GetDisplayName();      ValidationResult result = Attribute.GetValidationResult(metadata.Model, context);      if (result != ValidationResult.Success)      {          return new ModelValidationResult[] { new ModelValidationResult { Message = result.ErrorMessage } };      }      return new ModelValidationResult[0];  }
It would be great to inspect the global DependencyResolver and see whether there is any IServiceProvider type registered. If so, you can pass that into ValidationContext instead of passing null. I am completely unsure if this is possible to implement because at the first glance, it seems that the validation part doesn't have any knowledge of the HttpConfiguration. Also, this would be much more useful for the IValidatableObject validation. A sample use case scenario here is to check an existence of a value inside the database.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Add support for HTTP Strict Transport Security via an ActionFilter <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: Reposted here as requested by yishaigalatzer I would like to propose adding an HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) attribute into the core of ASP.NET MVC. According to OWASP, HSTS protects users from a number of threats, in particular man-in-the-middle attacks by not only forcing encrypted sessions, but also stopping attackers who use invalid digital certificates. Although developers can write the attribute themselves, I believe a fully test implementation would be a benefit and prevent inconsistencies within developer code (for example, developers may overlook the ability to add the sub domains suffix). If you think that this feature would add value, I will happily submit the code via a PR.
Issue closing motivation(s): Bug - Difficult to fix or to replicate####Bug - It will be fixed in future

TitleIssue: Consider supporting positional binding of route parameters <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: There are many times when using traditional routing that we need to map a route in the form {controller}/{action}/{parameterName} the issue is that we always bind based on the parameter name so id you have two actions that follow the same pattern but have different parameter names (like Details(int id) and Checkout (int customerId)) you need to declare two different routes (and be explicit on the controller/action name) in order to be able to bind two actions that follow the same routing pattern just for the fact that they have different parameter names. My suggestions is to consider solving this by allowing "positional" model binding, in which you can declare a route like the following {controller}/{action}/{0} and the binding process can choose to look for the parameter name first and if not found, try to find the position of the argument in the route value dictionary.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Return a 405 Method Not Allowed response instead of 404 <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
For the below controller, a request like POST /simplerest results in a 404 Not Found. Expected:
405 Method Not Allowed response with an Allow response header mentioning the list of methods supported by the resource identified by the url /simplerest. Currently MVC-WebAPI has this kind of support. 
public class SimpleRest : Controller    {        public string Get()        {            return "Get method";        }    }
From Spec:
10.4.6 405 Method Not Allowed
The method specified in the Request-Line is not allowed for the resource identified by the Request-URI. The response MUST include an Allow header containing a list of valid methods for the requested resource.

TitleIssue: relax the log4net dependency version <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: I can see that the latest log4net integration package (Common.Logging.Log4Net1215) depends strictly on log4net [2.0.5].  Would it be possible to relax it to something like [2.0.5,3.0), which will allow to update to a compatible (due to semantic versioning) log4net version without the need to update Common.Logging.Log4NetNNN every time? Also future versions of this package could have similar dependency as well. On top of that, I can see that there is no package for log4net 2.0.4 yet, I'd like to create one if that's not a problem - it could already use the less strict dependency.  The reason behind this is that having a strict dependency like this forces a wave of updates across the whole codebase which happens to share any project which gets updated to a new log4net version, which in case of my job is hundreds of projects in dozens of solutions, in dozens of repositories, which is basically an impossible (=too expensive) task.  I will create a pull request if I get an approval for such a change.

TitleIssue: Implement adapters to xunit-performance <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
The original idea by @AndyAyersMS:
How hard would it be for BDN to consume and do reasonable things with tests that contain xunit-performance attributes? That way we could still author perf tests like we do now but run them under either perf harness.
It should not be hard. In fact, the implementation of BenchmarkRunner.Run is pretty simple: 
public static Summary Run<T>(IConfig config = null) =>    BenchmarkRunnerCore.Run(BenchmarkConverter.TypeToBenchmarks(typeof(T), config), ToolchainExtensions.GetToolchain);public static Summary Run(Type type, IConfig config = null) =>    BenchmarkRunnerCore.Run(BenchmarkConverter.TypeToBenchmarks(type, config), ToolchainExtensions.GetToolchain);public static Summary Run(Type type, MethodInfo[] methods, IConfig config = null) =>    BenchmarkRunnerCore.Run(BenchmarkConverter.MethodsToBenchmarks(type, methods, config), ToolchainExtensions.GetToolchain);
BenchmarkConverter just takes method attributes and transform it to BenchmarkRunInfo which contains information about how to run the benchmarks without any knowledge about original attributes (see source code:
https://github.com/dotnet/BenchmarkDotNet/blob/v0.10.12/src/BenchmarkDotNet.Core/Running/BenchmarkConverter.cs)
It's pretty easy to make it pluggable and write XunitPerformanceBenchmarkConverter which transforms xunit-performance attributes to the BenchmarkDotNet represtnation.
I like this idea because it will allow to run all existed xunit benchmarks on BenchmarkDotNet without massive modifications of the source code.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

var summary = BenchmarkRunner.Init(             string BigOldMethod            (or a better suitable type)             string Alt_MethodToTest_1             string Alt_MethodToTest_2             \\ optional string TestName             \\ optional BenchmarkRunnerOptions   (required or optional)         ); (...)var i = BigOldMethod();var x = Alt_MethodToTest_1();var z = Alt_MethodToTest_2();Assert.AreEqual( i, x);Assert.AreEqual( i, z);(...)summary.ProduceOutput("TestName");
I see making 10x more use of the library if this could be make as this.
Do you think worth the effort? Thanks
Ricardo (from Portugal)

TitleIssue: Add Filling possibility <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
My benchmarks are written to measure time of working with object. The object is mutable, so I need new object every operation run. Currently I've work around this limitation by including construction of an object in operation. Workaround adds time for each operation but because object construction the same in all operations, all operations have the same "added time".
Proposed Filling ability it is new FillAttribute, that works similarly to SetupAttrbiute, but the filling method runs before operation instead before iteration, and filling method run time not affects operation time measurement.

TitleIssue: support runtime identifiers not supported by dotnet cli (project.json) <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
My environment:
  • dotnet core 1.0.0-preview2-003131 (for osx.10.11)
  • osx.10.12-x64
  • I use your sample app https://perfdotnet.github.io/BenchmarkDotNet/GettingStarted.htm
As far as I can see, Benchmark generates line "runtimes": { "osx.10.12-x64": { } } in project.json and uses the current machine's RID for that.
This line cause the error during dotnet restore because dotnet core sees unsupported runtime. If I remove this "runtimes": { "osx.10.12-x64": { } } line from project.json then I can run dotnet restore successfully. To solve this issue I can set DOTNET_RUNTIME_ID=osx.10.11-x64 environment variable, but it seems wired.
Here is a discussion on dotnet/cli#4281 for more details.

creates a logger named:

I believe the .<ExecuteAsync>d__13 part should not be included in logger name using the same method as in StackTraceUsageUtils.cs. This way the result would be:

TitleIssue: Nlog unusable on Google Pixel devices due to failing to load extensions (present or not) <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Type (choose one): Bug
NLog version: 4.4.12 (happens on 5.0.0-beta09 as well)
Platform: . Xamarin Android
  • What is the current result?
    On all google Pixel devices we have (a Pixel and 3 Pixel XLs), NLog fails to load the configuration file, so no logging occurs. We have many other types of phones, and this ONLY occurs on those Pixel devices.
This seems to happen at the point when extensions are attempted to be loaded. We are not using any extensions. The line that searches for them fails with an exception:
System.UnauthorizedAccessException: Access to the path '/' is denied.
This happens on this line in ConfigurationItemFactor.cs (line 378) 
var extensionDlls = Directory.GetFiles(assemblyLocation, "NLog*.dll")		.Select(Path.GetFileName)		.Where(x => !x.Equals("NLog.dll", StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase))		.Where(x => !x.Equals("NLog.UnitTests.dll", StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase))		.Where(x => !x.Equals("NLog.Extended.dll", StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase))		.Select(x => Path.Combine(assemblyLocation, x));
  • What is the expected result?
    The config file should be loaded and NLog should be able to log as configured.
  • Are there any work arrounds? yes/no
    I commented out that section searching for exceptions and NLog functions correctly for me again. This works since we aren't using any extensions, but the inability to search for them is a larger issue, seemingly with just Google Pixel devices.
Issue closing motivation(s): Not a bug####Change - Not relevant change
