As of now, the internalLogFile or NLOG_INTERNAL_LOG_FILE can only contain paths to files where NLog will write its internal log messages: 
<nlog internalLogFile="d:\logs
log.txt">setx /M NLOG_INTERNAL_LOG_FILE "d:\logs
log.txt"
When hosting multiple applications on a single machine, it would be nice to have those logs separated by Process ID, Application Pool Name or whatnot. This can be done by, as usual, adding an extra level of indirection: 
<nlog internalLogFile="%APPLICATION_LOG_ROOT%\%APP_POOL_ID%
log.txt">setx /M NLOG_INTERNAL_LOG_FILE "%APPLICATION_LOG_ROOT%\%APP_POOL_ID%
log.txt"
(in this example, %APPLICATION_LOG_ROOT% is a system-wide environment variable, and %APP_POOL_ID% is set automatically for each application by Internet Information Services). The required change looks trivial enough (InternalLogger.cs): 
    private static string GetSettingString(string configName, string envName)    {        // ...        // Existing code goes here        // ...        settingValue = Environment.ExpandEnvironmentVariables(settingValue);        return settingValue;    }
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: InternalLogger locks its own logging file <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Hi.
Maybe i am doing something wrong (hopefully), but i don't think so. We are using NLog with multiple targets and on multiple threads and the internal logger to log exceptions which could occure in our custom target implementation to a file. While testing this implementation we encountered the following error:
VS2015 Output:
TearDown : System.IO.IOException : The process cannot access the file "C:\logs\internalException.log" because it is being used by another process.
Our configuration looks like this: 
public class LoggerFactory : ILoggerFactory<LoggerConfigurationBase>{	public Contracts.ILogger Create(LoggerConfigurationBase loggerConfig, InternalLogConfiguration internalConfiguration)    {                TargetWithLayout target = loggerConfig.GetTarget();                    ConfigurationItemFactory.Default.LayoutRenderers.RegisterDefinition("LogEntryLayoutRenderer", typeof(LogEntryLayoutRenderer));        target.Layout = "${LogEntryLayoutRenderer}";            LoggingRule loggingRule = new LoggingRule(loggerConfig.LoggerName, LogLevel.Info, target);            LogManager.Configuration.LoggingRules.Add(loggingRule);            LogManager.ReconfigExistingLoggers();        if (internalConfiguration != null)        {            LogManager.ThrowExceptions = internalConfiguration.ThrowExceptions;            InternalLogger.LogFile = internalConfiguration.Filename;            InternalLogger.LogLevel = this.ConvertFromSeverity(internalConfiguration.Severity);            InternalLogger.LogToTrace = internalConfiguration.LogToTrace;        }            return new ViaLogger(LogManager.GetLogger(loggerConfig.LoggerName));    }}
The Test we are looking like this: 
[TestFixture][ExcludeFromCodeCoverage][Category(TestCategories.IntegrationTest)][Category("ExceptionHandlingTest")][Parallelizable(ParallelScope.None)]public class ExceptionHandlingTests{    private readonly String internalExceptionLogFile = "C:/logs/internalException.log";	[OneTimeSetUp]    public void ClassSetUp()    {        if (File.Exists(this.internalExceptionLogFile))        {            File.Delete(this.internalExceptionLogFile);        }    }    [OneTimeTearDown]    public void ClassTearDown()    {        if (File.Exists(this.internalExceptionLogFile))        {            //System.IO.IOException : The process cannot access the file "Disk\Folder\internalException.log" because it is being used by another process.            File.Delete(this.internalExceptionLogFile);        }    }    [SetUp]    public void TestSetup()    {        Thread.CurrentThread.CurrentUICulture = new CultureInfo("en-US");    }		[Test]	[TestCase(TestName = "Log one entry into text file with invalid path should log exception into internal log")]	//Test Failed: InternalLogFile contains not expected error message. Expected: True, But was:  False	public void LogTextFile_PathNotexists_ShouldWriteExceptionInInternalTextFile()	{		LoggerFactory textFileFactory = new LoggerFactory();		ILogger textFilelogger = textFileFactory.Create(			new TextfileConfiguration(				"ExceptionHandlingTextFileLoggerWithInternalLogFile",				"ExceptionHandlingTestTextFileTarget",				"ABC:/Path_Not_Exists/ExceptionHandlingTest.txt"),			new InternalLogConfiguration()			{				Filename = this.internalExceptionLogFile,				LogToTrace = true,				Severity = Severities.Trace			}		);		textFilelogger.Log(Severities.Info, "TextFile TestMessage");		FileAssert.Exists(this.internalExceptionLogFile);			String fileContent = new StreamReader(this.internalExceptionLogFile).ReadToEnd();		String expectedErrorMessage = "Error Error has been raised. Exception: System.NotSupportedException: The given path's format is not supported.";		Assert.That(fileContent.Contains(expectedErrorMessage), Is.True, "InternalLogFile contains not expected error message");	}		[Test]	[TestCase(TestName = "Log one entry into elastic search with invalid url should log exception into internal log")]	//Test passes	public void LogElasticSearch_UrlNotexists_ShouldWriteExceptionInInternalTextFile()	{		Uri[] nodeUris =		{			new Uri("https://domain-not.exists")		};		LoggerFactory elasticSearchfactory = new LoggerFactory();		ILogger elasticSearchlogger = elasticSearchfactory.Create(			new ElasticsearchConfiguration(				"ExceptionHandlingElasticSearchLoggerWithInternalLogFile",				"ExceptionHandlingTestElasticTarget",				"ExceptionHandlingTest",				nodeUris),			new InternalLogConfiguration()			{				Filename = this.internalExceptionLogFile,				LogToTrace = true			}		);		elasticSearchlogger.Log(Severities.Info, "ElasticSearch TestMessage");		FileAssert.Exists(this.internalExceptionLogFile);			String fileContent = new StreamReader(this.internalExceptionLogFile).ReadToEnd();		String expectedErrorMessage = "PingFailure: Node: https://domain-not.exists/ Exception: PipelineException";		Assert.That(fileContent.Contains(expectedErrorMessage), Is.True, "InternalLogFile contains not expected error message");	}}
As you can see we are using nunit to perform our tests. The issue only happen when we run these to test together. In my understanding the file used by the internal logger should be closed after an logentry is written and the filehandle should be released, which it doesnt't do. My question now: Am i doing something wrong? If no, is there a solution/workaround for this issue?

TitleIssue: proposal: support bufferization in user code and provide method that can flush several events at once <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Situation: my user code bufferize "verbose" tracing messages till the system event (e.g. "interesting input" or exception ) and then flush them.
For better performance (as I imagine logging: for each logging operation there is expensive "open destination stream" operation ) it would be nice to have new Logger method like:
public void Log(IEnumerable<LogEventInfo> logEvents);
that accepts several events. Now it is absent. (Do not worry about real time datetime, stacktrace and other attributes - If user would need them there is possibility to add them as properties) There is of course possibility to log bufferized events at once as one big concatenated text, but this is not very attractive since there is strong feeling that bufferized event's record should no differ to much from not bufferized (some new custom properties that user can add by himself is OK)... Thank you for your work.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed####Bug - Impossible to fix the issue or too expensive change

TitleIssue: NLog 3.2.1 does not work with two (inner\outer) log wrappers <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
If you write a log wrapper and give it the correct declaring type it works fine as long as there is only one wrapper. If you have two wrappers it stops at the first one even if you give it a declaring type of the second one. This does not happen on v3.1.0.0. Please fix. 
<target name="console" type="Console"    layout="${callsite:className=True:fileName=False:includeSourcePath=False:methodName=True} ${message}" />
class InnerLoggerWrapper{    public Type BoundaryType { get; set; }    private readonly Logger _logger;    public InnerLoggerWrapper(string name)    {        BoundaryType = typeof (InnerLoggerWrapper);        _logger = LogManager.GetLogger(name);    }    public void Log(string message)    {        _logger.Log(BoundaryType, new LogEventInfo(LogLevel.Debug, _logger.Name, message));    }}class OuterLoggerWrapper{    private readonly InnerLoggerWrapper _inner;    public OuterLoggerWrapper(string name)    {        _inner = new InnerLoggerWrapper(name) {BoundaryType = typeof (OuterLoggerWrapper)};    }    public void Log(string message)    {        _inner.Log(message);    }}class Program{    static void Main(string[] args)    {        var l = new OuterLoggerWrapper("test");        l.Log("test");        Console.ReadKey(true);    }}
This output's "ConsoleApplication1.Program.Main test" with nlog version 3.1 which is correct. This output's "ConsoleApplication1.InnerLoggerWrapper.Log test" with nlog version 3.2.1 which is wrong.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: FileTarget rotation is not multiprocess-safe <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: I found (unfortunately in the hardest way possible - by receiving a useless set of logs from a production issue) that FileTarget rotation is not multiprocess-safe - there may be races between one process checking that rotation is needed, another process performing rotation, yet another process also performing rotation etc. I implemented a fix in "double-checked locking" style: I use a multiprocess mutex and double-check ShouldAutoArchive within the mutex. This seems to work fine: I did a test where several instances of an app were constantly writing consecutive numbers to the same log file, with a small rotation threshold (20kb), and I checked that not a single number was missed. Without double-checked locking, or without the solution altogether, there were large gaps. See my implementation in commit jkff/NLog@8399f04 . The fix I introduced has since survived several months of extremely heavy production testing, so I think it should be safe to merge.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Concurrent Access in File Target fails <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue:
Reported in the forum at post: http://nlog-project.org/forum.html#nabble-tc1685753|a1685753 I am attempting to use NLog in a multiple app domain process. The log file has the following target ---------------------------------------------- <target name="DefaultLogFile" concurrentWriteAttemptDelay="1" concurrentWrites="true" concurrentWriteAttempts = "10" keepFileOpen="false" autoFlush="false" deleteOldFileOnStartup="true" xsi:type="File" layout="${level:uppercase=true} ${message}" fileName="${basedir}/Log.log" /> ----------------------------------------------- The nlog internal trace file produces the following exception. ----------------------------------------------- 2008-06-02 11:34:05.7497 Error Target exception: System.IO.FileLoadException: The process cannot access the file because it is being used by another process. (Exception from HRESULT: 0x80070020) at System.Runtime.InteropServices.Marshal.ThrowExceptionForHRInternal(Int32 errorCode, IntPtr errorInfo) at NLog.Internal.FileAppenders.BaseFileAppender.WindowsCreateFile(String fileName, Boolean allowConcurrentWrite) at NLog.Internal.FileAppenders.BaseFileAppender.TryCreateFileStream(Boolean allowConcurrentWrite) at NLog.Internal.FileAppenders.BaseFileAppender.CreateFileStream(Boolean allowConcurrentWrite) at NLog.Internal.FileAppenders.RetryingMultiProcessFileAppender.Write(Byte[] bytes) at NLog.Targets.FileTarget.WriteToFile(String fileName, Byte[] bytes, Boolean justData) at NLog.Targets.FileTarget.Write(LogEventInfo logEvent) at NLog.LoggerImpl.Write(Type loggerType, TargetWithFilterChain targets, LogEventInfo logEvent, LogFactory factory) ---------------------------------------------------------- The following line in RetryingMultiProcessFileAppender.Write(byte[] bytes) is suspect using (FileStream fileStream = CreateFileStream(false)) If the above value is true rather than false then no exceptions occur in the internal trace file. The false value means that in the BaseFileAppender.WindowsCreateFile() method it will end up opening the file without the FILE_SHARE_WRITE share value set. Thus it cannot succeed with other open attempts. So the question would be is the something in the above target that is inappropriate for current access? Nothing that I have tried alters that Retrying class is in use. Comments:
deleteOldFileOnStartup options Reported in the forum at post: http://nlog-project.org/forum.html#nabble-tc1686002|a1686002 Hi It seems that deleteOldFileOnStartup somehow make logger to erase fist few lines from the file including for example header. This is a config file As long as deleteOldFileOnStartup is true, the +++++++++++++ never appears in the log file (along with some of the program info which is logged by Main(). Here are examples of log file deleteOldFileOnStartup="false" +++++++++++++
22/10/2008 11:32:48| INFO| 10|---------------------------------------------
22/10/2008 11:32:48| INFO| 10|RB: App starts
22/10/2008 11:32:48| INFO| 10|---------------------------------------------
22/10/2008 11:32:50| INFO| 10|RB: DropDownList: executing prSelect
22/10/2008 11:32:51| INFO| 10|RB: DropDownList: executing prProcessView_Select
... deleteOldFileOnStartup="true" 22/10/2008 11:34:08| INFO| 10|RB: DropDownList: executing prSelect
22/10/2008 11:34:08| INFO| 10|RB: DropDownList: executing prProcessView_Select
.... Cheers, Igor NLogBugTroll wrote Oct 6 2009 at 10:02 PM Testing indicates that the following option is what impacts this. deleteOldFileOnStartup="true" Although conceptually easy to understand why this causes a problem it means that functionality is lost particularly when it is AppDomains rather than actual different processes in use
Issue closing motivation(s): Not a bug

TitleIssue: Explore more physical feedback for integer sliders <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: Currently notched sliders snap instantly to their new positions, it would be really nice to have some sort of graphical/physical effect that made things more natural.  We could explore a couple of different options.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

TitleIssue: Sort elements along an axis to allow for transparent shaders <U+00B7> "
DescriptionIssue: When using transparent shaders we will need to sort elements in some way to ensure that they are represented correctly.  The Unity GUI way of doing things is to have the hierarchy traversal specify the draw order, but that ends up biting us a whole lot if people move their head around since gui elements end up overlapping each other in ways they should not.  This should be a checkbox so that we don't waste time sorting things when using an opaque shader.  We should use some sort of sorting algorithm that performs well on already-sorted data.  Since the view of the user isn't going to be changing drastically from frame to frame, the elements will probably stay in almost sorted order frame-to-frame.
Issue closing motivation(s): Feature request/enhancement - Feature request/enhancement already implemented or not needed

private async void GeneratePdf()    {      var path = Path.GetDirectoryName(System.Reflection.Assembly.GetEntryAssembly().Location);      var generatedPdfFile = Path.Combine(path, @"testPDF.pdf");      var chromeSettings = new PdfPrintSettings();      var htmlFile = Path.Combine(path, @"Html2\Hacker News.html");      using(var chromium = GetOffsceenChromium(htmlFile))      {        var pdfFileSaved = await chromium.PrintToPdfAsync(generatedPdfFile, chromeSettings);        if (pdfFileSaved)        {          //Thread.Sleep(10);  // <-- uncomment this line and no exception happens          using (var testStream = new FileStream(generatedPdfFile, FileMode.Open))          {             // access the file for read --> exception is thrown. PDF file is still in use by Chromium.          }        }      }    }
